description:
A universe is created consisting exactly of n galaxies. The universe is a connected undirected graph with n−1 edges. Each galaxy g of this universe has a density ag assigned to it.

Let dist(x,y) be the distance between the galaxies x and y. The distance between the galaxies is the number of edges on the simple path between them.

Let's define the beauty of the universe as the following value: firstly, let's fix some galaxy of the universe. Let it be g. Then the beauty of the universe is ∑i=1ndist(i,g)⋅ai, where ai is the density of galaxy i.

Your task is to calculate the maximum possible beauty of the universe if you can choose g arbitrarily.

Input:
The first line contains one integer n, the number of galaxies in the universe (1≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of the input contains n integers a1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤2⋅105), where ai is the density of the galaxy.

Each of the next n−1 lines describes an edge of the universe. Edge i is denoted by two integers ui and vi, the labels of galaxies it connects (1≤ui,vi≤n, ui≠vi).

It is guaranteed that the given edges form a universe of the structure of a tree.

Output:
Print one integer — the maximum possible beauty of the universe if you can choose any galaxy as g.

Examples

input

8

9 4 1 7 10 1 6 5

1 2

2 3

1 4

1 5

5 6

5 7

5 8

output

121


input

1

1337

output

0
title: Beauty of the Universe
